sv:property.sv:value:
declare LoanApplication amount: Integer approved: Boolean deposit: Integer approvedRate: Integer lengthYears: Integer explanation: String insuranceCost: Integer end
declare Applicant age: Integer applicationDate: java.util.Date creditRating: String name: String approved: Boolean end
declare IncomeSource amount: Integer type: String end
declare Bankruptcy amountOwed: Integer yearOfOccurrence: Integer end
Test really basic validation, common sense stuff
We don't want bankrupt people since 1990, or if their amount was over a certain amount

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.
Obviously we only want people who can pay stuff back

#created on: Mar 27, 2012
rule "riskyadults" ruleflow-group "calculation"
when #conditions driver : Driver(age > 24, numberOfAccidents > 0 || numberOfTickets >= 2) policy : Policy(price == 0, policyType == "AUTO") then #actions modify(policy) {setPrice(300)} System.out.println("fired rule " + kcontext.getRule().getName()); end

#created on: Mar 27, 2012
rule "riskyyouths" ruleflow-group "calculation"
when #conditions driver : Driver(age > 17 && < 25, numberOfAccidents > 0 || numberOfTickets >= 2) policy : Policy(price == 0, policyType == "AUTO") then #actions modify(policy) {setPrice(700)} System.out.println("fired rule " + kcontext.getRule().getName()); end

#created on: Mar 27, 2012
rule "safeadults" ruleflow-group "calculation"
when #conditions driver : Driver(age > 24, numberOfAccidents == 0, numberOfTickets < 2) policy : Policy(price == 0, policyType == "AUTO")
then #actions modify(policy) {setPrice(120)} System.out.println("fired rule " + kcontext.getRule().getName()); end

#created on: Mar 27, 2012
rule "safeyouths" ruleflow-group "calculation"
when #conditions driver : Driver(age > 17 && < 25, numberOfAccidents < 1, numberOfTickets <= 1) policy : Policy(price == 0, policyType == "AUTO") then #actions modify(policy) {setPrice(450)} System.out.println("fired rule " + kcontext.getRule().getName());
end

#created on: Mar 27, 2012
rule "PriceMultipleVehicles" ruleflow-group "total" # dialect "mvel" salience -10
#For all vehicles for the same driver #Then create a master policy with price = the sum of the individual policy prices
when #conditions $driver : Driver() $policyM : Policy(policyType == "MASTER", price == 0) # can bind either total to the primitive or to the wrapper # accumulate function coerces result as specified Number( total : intValue > 0 ) from accumulate( Policy( policyType != "MASTER", $price : price > 0), sum( $price ) ) then #actions modify ($policyM) {setPrice(total)} System.out.println("fired rule " + kcontext.getRule().getName() + " Price is " + $policyM.getPrice() ); end

Archived Item on Wed Oct 01 12:54:56 GMT+1000 2008

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.
